summary: This is an email chain from August 2020 between FBI personnel discussing discovery requests for documentation related to the forensic extraction of data from devices seized in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The emails concern the timing and nature of paperwork (like CART notes and FD-302s) to be provided to the defense.

persons.name: I. (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator, Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: The primary author/coordinator in the email chain, discussing the process for generating documentation (CART notes) for device extractions in the Epstein case and their personal travel schedule.

persons.name: (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: Special Agent, FBI New York Field Office
persons.context: An FBI Special Agent relaying a request from the defense counsel for paperwork documenting data extractions from seized devices and inquiring about the availability of such documentation.

connections.description: FBI colleagues communicating about a procedural matter regarding evidence documentation for the Epstein case.

events.title: Defense Request for Extraction Documentation
events.description: The defense counsel requests CART paperwork and FD-302s regarding the extraction of data from all devices seized during the Epstein investigation.

events.title: FBI Discussion on Documentation Protocol
events.description: FBI personnel discuss the standard protocol that documentation (CART notes) is generated after the forensic review is complete, not during the ongoing extraction process.

keyFacts: The defense in the Epstein case was actively seeking discovery materials in August 2020, specifically paperwork documenting forensic data extractions from seized devices.
FBI's Computer Analysis Response Team (CART) was involved in processing devices seized from Epstein's properties.
Standard FBI procedure, as explained, is to generate final documentation (CART notes) only after the complete forensic review, not to provide interim paperwork.
The email references FD-302s (FBI interview/evidence reports) related to the device extractions as another item requested by the defense.
The correspondence is explicitly 'SUBJECT TO PROTECTIVE ORDER,' indicating sensitive or restricted discovery material.
